title: HTML TAG INJECTION ON PROFILE NAME

profile.name: GitLab
profile.about: A single application for the entire software development lifecycle.

vulnerability_information:
Allows me to change the profile name to an image tag and convert it into an html code and this tag appears perfectly on the "snippets" page. Suppose I include an image tag with source and when another user sees it on the "https://gitlab.com/snippets/1718284" page it will appear an image of an anonymous. I can also add a header tag in the profile name with the tag "

HACKED BY TALAOHU28

" and will look perfect on the same page "https://gitlab.com/snippets/1718284". Other tags that run perfectly include:
Here's the complete payload I've made as the profile name

HACKED BY TALAOHU28


I WANT TO BACK FREE


## Impact other users can see the page "https://gitlab.com/snippets/1718284" as if being hacked by hackers
vulnerability_information_html:
Allows me to change the profile name to an image tag <img src="........"/> and convert it into an html code and this tag appears perfectly on the "snippets" page.

Suppose I include an image tag with source <img src="http://progress28.web.id/abc.jpg"> and when another user sees it on the "https://gitlab.com/snippets/1718284" page it will appear an image of an anonymous.

I can also add a header tag in the profile name with the tag "<h1>HACKED BY TALAOHU28</h1>" and will look perfect on the same page "https://gitlab.com/snippets/1718284".

Other tags that run perfectly include:
</br>
<div></div>
<a href=""></a>
<b></b>

Here's the complete payload I've made as the profile name

</br><h1>HACKED BY TALAOHU28</h1><img src="http://progress28.web.id/abc.jpg"></br><h1>I WANT TO BACK FREE</h1></br>

Impact

other users can see the page "https://gitlab.com/snippets/1718284" as if being hacked by hackers

activities.message:
Hi @talaohu28.

Because you commented on a snippet I had just created, I actually saw this exploit on gitlab.com and blocked the account, then saw your report here, so I've unblocked you again.

Thanks for reporting this! I've created a confidential issue to make sure this is resolved, and our security team will keep you updated here on its progress.

Thanks!
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @talaohu28.

Because you commented on a snippet I had just created, I actually saw this exploit on gitlab.com and blocked the account, then saw your report here, so I've unblocked you again.

Thanks for reporting this! I've created a confidential issue to make sure this is resolved, and our security team will keep you updated here on its progress.

Thanks!

activities.message:
Hi @talaohu28 ,

A limited set of HTML tags are allowed in user names.  Our initial investigation shows that any scripting related tags and attributes are being removed correctly before being rendered.  Do you have an example that includes unintended script execution?  If not, this report will most likely be closed as Not Applicable, resulting in a loss of reputation here on HackerOne.

In addition, this is not in any way an SSRF, as those requests are from your own browser and not a GitLab server, and the use of `Referer` header is consistent with content fetched by a browser from a different domain than the containing document.

Regards,
Antony
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @talaohu28 ,

Do you have an example that includes unintended script execution? If not, this report will most likely be closed as Not Applicable, resulting in a loss of reputation here on HackerOne.

In addition, this is not in any way an SSRF, as those requests are from your own browser and not a GitLab server, and the use of Referer header is consistent with content fetched by a browser from a different domain than the containing document.

Regards,
Antony

activities.message:
Other tags that run perfectly include:
It does not look great if the username allows a user to input html tags. @rspeicher @asaba It is clear that a html injection bug exists on the username and allows an attacker to change the username into a link to a malware site or other malicious site. Regards, Talaohu28
activities.markdown_message:
Other tags that run perfectly include:
</br>
<div></div>
<a href=""></a>
<b></b>

It does not look great if the username allows a user to input html tags. @rspeicher @asaba
It is clear that a html injection bug exists on the username and allows an attacker to change the username into a link to a malware site or other malicious site.

Regards,

Talaohu28

activities.message:
Hi @talaohu28 ,

The `<a>` being passed through is an inconsistency that could lead to a user clicking on a bad link.  In future reports, providing an more complete list of capabilities and restrictions as well comparisons to existing behavior will help the triage process.  We will continue to track internally and will disclose this publicly 30 days after the patch is released.

"Does not look great" is not an actionable description of system behavior and is irrelevant to the report.

Regards,
Antony

activities.message:
Hi Mr. @rspeicher and @asaba 


I tried again to exploit the html injection tag hole in the username feature to implement account hijacking activity by creating a link that pointed to a page resembling a github page, allowing a user to fool because he thought he was on the "https://gitlab.com/users/sign_in" when he is on a fake page that allows the attacker to get the account from the concerned. On that fake page I also added the message "You have logged from the system, please login again" to make it appear as if he has been woven from the system and prompted to login again after clicking my username. 

For my reproduction stages attach screenshots and videos.


Note:
* Example page phishing --> http://progress28.web.id/gitlab-phishing/
* This type of attack will work very well if victim opens it through the browser on its mobile phone
* The username and password will be stored on the page http://progress28.web.id/gitlab-phishing/data.txt


Impact:
Potential to get the original username and password from victim

Regards,

Talaohu28
activities.markdown_message:
Hi Mr. @rspeicher and @asaba

I tried again to exploit the html injection tag hole in the username feature to implement account hijacking activity by creating a link that pointed to a page resembling a github page, allowing a user to fool because he thought he was on the "https://gitlab.com/users/sign_in" when he is on a fake page that allows the attacker to get the account from the concerned. On that fake page I also added the message "You have logged from the system, please login again" to make it appear as if he has been woven from the system and prompted to login again after clicking my username.

For my reproduction stages attach screenshots and videos.

Note:

  • Example page phishing --> http://progress28.web.id/gitlab-phishing/
  • This type of attack will work very well if victim opens it through the browser on its mobile phone
  • The username and password will be stored on the page http://progress28.web.id/gitlab-phishing/data.txt

Impact:
Potential to get the original username and password from victim

Regards,

Talaohu28

James
